A riot broke out in a city, and many shops had been looted and some had been burned during the riots. Goods of all kinds were in piles or strewn about the sidewalk. During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. At his arraignment, the judge advised the defendant of his right to have counsel appointed for him. The defendant, however, told the judge that he wanted to represent himself and waive his right to a jury trial. The judge then questioned the defendant at length about his demands. The defendant indicated that he had no previous legal experience. He told the judge that the reason he didn't want a court-appointed attorney to represent him was because he didn't trust lawyers. The judge did not find the defendant's reasons for representing himself to be persuasive and appointed an attorney to represent him. Thereafter, an attorney was appointed by the court to represent the defendant. The attorney told the court that the defendant wanted a non-jury trial. However, at the prosecution's request, the court impaneled a jury. The defendant was subsequently convicted by the jury and sentenced to six months imprisonment. In addition, the defendant was ordered to reimburse the state $450 to cover the cost of his attorney. This reimbursement order was made pursuant to a relevant statute in effect at the time of the defendant's arrest. The defendant appeals both the conviction and the reimbursement order. The appellate court should

A) affirm both the conviction and the reimbursement order.
B) affirm the conviction because the defendant was provided with an attorney, but reverse the reimbursement order.
C) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was not properly informed of his rights.
D) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not informed of the consequences of waiving his right to a jury trial, but affirm the reimbursement order.
E) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not allowed to represent himself, but affirm the reimbursement order.
F) affirm the conviction, but not the reimbursement order.

During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. A riot broke out in a city, and many shops had been looted and some had been burned during the riots. Goods of all kinds were in piles or strewn about the sidewalk. During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. At his arraignment, the judge advised the defendant of his right to have counsel appointed for him. The defendant, however, told the judge that he wanted to represent himself and waive his right to a jury trial. The judge then questioned the defendant at length about his demands. The defendant indicated that he had no previous legal experience. He told the judge that the reason he didn't want a court-appointed attorney to represent him was because he didn't trust lawyers. The judge did not find the defendant's reasons for representing himself to be persuasive and appointed an attorney to represent him. Thereafter, an attorney was appointed by the court to represent the defendant. The attorney told the court that the defendant wanted a non-jury trial. However, at the prosecution's request, the court impaneled a jury. The defendant was subsequently convicted by the jury and sentenced to six months imprisonment. In addition, the defendant was ordered to reimburse the state $450 to cover the cost of his attorney. This reimbursement order was made pursuant to a relevant statute in effect at the time of the defendant's arrest. The defendant appeals both the conviction and the reimbursement order. The appellate court should

A) affirm both the conviction and the reimbursement order.
B) affirm the conviction because the defendant was provided with an attorney, but reverse the reimbursement order.
C) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was not properly informed of his rights.
D) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not informed of the consequences of waiving his right to a jury trial, but affirm the reimbursement order.
E) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not allowed to represent himself, but affirm the reimbursement order.
F) affirm the conviction, but not the reimbursement order.
G) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was denied the right to represent himself.
H) reverse the reimbursement order because it exceeds the maximum fine for grand larceny, but affirm the conviction.
I) affirm the reimbursement order, but not the conviction.
J) reverse the conviction because he was denied the right to a non-jury trial, but not the reimbursement order.

additional_args.input_str:
A riot broke out in a city, and many shops had been looted and some had been burned during the riots. Goods of all kinds were in piles or strewn about the sidewalk. During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. At his arraignment, the judge advised the defendant of his right to have counsel appointed for him. The defendant, however, told the judge that he wanted to represent himself and waive his right to a jury trial. The judge then questioned the defendant at length about his demands. The defendant indicated that he had no previous legal experience. He told the judge that the reason he didn't want a court-appointed attorney to represent him was because he didn't trust lawyers. The judge did not find the defendant's reasons for representing himself to be persuasive and appointed an attorney to represent him. Thereafter, an attorney was appointed by the court to represent the defendant. The attorney told the court that the defendant wanted a non-jury trial. However, at the prosecution's request, the court impaneled a jury. The defendant was subsequently convicted by the jury and sentenced to six months imprisonment. In addition, the defendant was ordered to reimburse the state $450 to cover the cost of his attorney. This reimbursement order was made pursuant to a relevant statute in effect at the time of the defendant's arrest. The defendant appeals both the conviction and the reimbursement order. The appellate court should

A) affirm both the conviction and the reimbursement order.
B) affirm the conviction because the defendant was provided with an attorney, but reverse the reimbursement order.
C) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was not properly informed of his rights.
D) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not informed of the consequences of waiving his right to a jury trial, but affirm the reimbursement order.
E) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not allowed to represent himself, but affirm the reimbursement order.
F) affirm the conviction, but not the reimbursement order.
G) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was denied the right to represent himself.
H) reverse the reimbursement order because it exceeds the maximum fine for grand larceny, but affirm the conviction.
I) affirm the reimbursement order, but not the conviction.
J) reverse the conviction because he was denied the right to a non-jury trial, but not the reimbursement order.

additional_args.input_str:
A riot broke out in a city, and many shops had been looted and some had been burned during the riots. Goods of all kinds were in piles or strewn about the sidewalk. During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. At his arraignment, the judge advised the defendant of his right to have counsel appointed for him. The defendant, however, told the judge that he wanted to represent himself and waive his right to a jury trial. The judge then questioned the defendant at length about his demands. The defendant indicated that he had no previous legal experience. He told the judge that the reason he didn't want a court-appointed attorney to represent him was because he didn't trust lawyers. The judge did not find the defendant's reasons for representing himself to be persuasive and appointed an attorney to represent him. Thereafter, an attorney was appointed by the court to represent the defendant. The attorney told the court that the defendant wanted a non-jury trial. However, at the prosecution's request, the court impaneled a jury. The defendant was subsequently convicted by the jury and sentenced to six months imprisonment. In addition, the defendant was ordered to reimburse the state $450 to cover the cost of his attorney. This reimbursement order was made pursuant to a relevant statute in effect at the time of the defendant's arrest. The defendant appeals both the conviction and the reimbursement order. The appellate court should

A) affirm both the conviction and the reimbursement order.
B) affirm the conviction because the defendant was provided with an attorney, but reverse the reimbursement order.
C) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was not properly informed of his rights.
D) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not informed of the consequences of waiving his right to a jury trial, but affirm the reimbursement order.
E) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not allowed to represent himself, but affirm the reimbursement order.
F) affirm the conviction, but not the reimbursement order.
G) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was denied the right to represent himself.
H) reverse the reimbursement order because it exceeds the maximum fine for grand larceny, but affirm the conviction.
I) affirm the reimbursement order, but not the conviction.
J) reverse the conviction because he was denied the right to a non-jury trial, but not the reimbursement order.

additional_args.input_str:
A riot broke out in a city, and many shops had been looted and some had been burned during the riots. Goods of all kinds were in piles or strewn about the sidewalk. During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. At his arraignment, the judge advised the defendant of his right to have counsel appointed for him. The defendant, however, told the judge that he wanted to represent himself and waive his right to a jury trial. The judge then questioned the defendant at length about his demands. The defendant indicated that he had no previous legal experience. He told the judge that the reason he didn't want a court-appointed attorney to represent him was because he didn't trust lawyers. The judge did not find the defendant's reasons for representing himself to be persuasive and appointed an attorney to represent him. Thereafter, an attorney was appointed by the court to represent the defendant. The attorney told the court that the defendant wanted a non-jury trial. However, at the prosecution's request, the court impaneled a jury. The defendant was subsequently convicted by the jury and sentenced to six months imprisonment. In addition, the defendant was ordered to reimburse the state $450 to cover the cost of his attorney. This reimbursement order was made pursuant to a relevant statute in effect at the time of the defendant's arrest. The defendant appeals both the conviction and the reimbursement order. The appellate court should

A) affirm both the conviction and the reimbursement order.
B) affirm the conviction because the defendant was provided with an attorney, but reverse the reimbursement order.
C) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was not properly informed of his rights.
D) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not informed of the consequences of waiving his right to a jury trial, but affirm the reimbursement order.
E) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not allowed to represent himself, but affirm the reimbursement order.
F) affirm the conviction, but not the reimbursement order.
G) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was denied the right to represent himself.
H) reverse the reimbursement order because it exceeds the maximum fine for grand larceny, but affirm the conviction.
I) affirm the reimbursement order, but not the conviction.
J) reverse the conviction because he was denied the right to a non-jury trial, but not the reimbursement order.

additional_args.input_str:
A riot broke out in a city, and many shops had been looted and some had been burned during the riots. Goods of all kinds were in piles or strewn about the sidewalk. During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. At his arraignment, the judge advised the defendant of his right to have counsel appointed for him. The defendant, however, told the judge that he wanted to represent himself and waive his right to a jury trial. The judge then questioned the defendant at length about his demands. The defendant indicated that he had no previous legal experience. He told the judge that the reason he didn't want a court-appointed attorney to represent him was because he didn't trust lawyers. The judge did not find the defendant's reasons for representing himself to be persuasive and appointed an attorney to represent him. Thereafter, an attorney was appointed by the court to represent the defendant. The attorney told the court that the defendant wanted a non-jury trial. However, at the prosecution's request, the court impaneled a jury. The defendant was subsequently convicted by the jury and sentenced to six months imprisonment. In addition, the defendant was ordered to reimburse the state $450 to cover the cost of his attorney. This reimbursement order was made pursuant to a relevant statute in effect at the time of the defendant's arrest. The defendant appeals both the conviction and the reimbursement order. The appellate court should

A) affirm both the conviction and the reimbursement order.
B) affirm the conviction because the defendant was provided with an attorney, but reverse the reimbursement order.
C) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was not properly informed of his rights.
D) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not informed of the consequences of waiving his right to a jury trial, but affirm the reimbursement order.
E) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not allowed to represent himself, but affirm the reimbursement order.
F) affirm the conviction, but not the reimbursement order.
G) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was denied the right to represent himself.
H) reverse the reimbursement order because it exceeds the maximum fine for grand larceny, but affirm the conviction.
I) affirm the reimbursement order, but not the conviction.
J) reverse the conviction because he was denied the right to a non-jury trial, but not the reimbursement order.

additional_args.input_str:
A riot broke out in a city, and many shops had been looted and some had been burned during the riots. Goods of all kinds were in piles or strewn about the sidewalk. During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. At his arraignment, the judge advised the defendant of his right to have counsel appointed for him. The defendant, however, told the judge that he wanted to represent himself and waive his right to a jury trial. The judge then questioned the defendant at length about his demands. The defendant indicated that he had no previous legal experience. He told the judge that the reason he didn't want a court-appointed attorney to represent him was because he didn't trust lawyers. The judge did not find the defendant's reasons for representing himself to be persuasive and appointed an attorney to represent him. Thereafter, an attorney was appointed by the court to represent the defendant. The attorney told the court that the defendant wanted a non-jury trial. However, at the prosecution's request, the court impaneled a jury. The defendant was subsequently convicted by the jury and sentenced to six months imprisonment. In addition, the defendant was ordered to reimburse the state $450 to cover the cost of his attorney. This reimbursement order was made pursuant to a relevant statute in effect at the time of the defendant's arrest. The defendant appeals both the conviction and the reimbursement order. The appellate court should

A) affirm both the conviction and the reimbursement order.
B) affirm the conviction because the defendant was provided with an attorney, but reverse the reimbursement order.
C) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was not properly informed of his rights.
D) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not informed of the consequences of waiving his right to a jury trial, but affirm the reimbursement order.
E) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not allowed to represent himself, but affirm the reimbursement order.
F) affirm the conviction, but not the reimbursement order.
G) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was denied the right to represent himself.
H) reverse the reimbursement order because it exceeds the maximum fine for grand larceny, but affirm the conviction.
I) affirm the reimbursement order, but not the conviction.
J) reverse the conviction because he was denied the right to a non-jury trial, but not the reimbursement order.

A riot broke out in a city, and many shops had been looted and some had been burned during the riots. Goods of all kinds were in piles or strewn about the sidewalk. During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. At his arraignment, the judge advised the defendant of his right to have counsel appointed for him. The defendant, however, told the judge that he wanted to represent himself and waive his right to a jury trial. The judge then questioned the defendant at length about his demands. The defendant indicated that he had no previous legal experience. He told the judge that the reason he didn't want a court-appointed attorney to represent him was because he didn't trust lawyers. The judge did not find the defendant's reasons for representing himself to be persuasive and appointed an attorney to represent him. Thereafter, an attorney was appointed by the court to represent the defendant. The attorney told the court that the defendant wanted a non-jury trial. However, at the prosecution's request, the court impaneled a jury. The defendant was subsequently convicted by the jury and sentenced to six months imprisonment. In addition, the defendant was ordered to reimburse the state $450 to cover the cost of his attorney. This reimbursement order was made pursuant to a relevant statute in effect at the time of the defendant's arrest. The defendant appeals both the conviction and the reimbursement order. The appellate court should

A) affirm both the conviction and the reimbursement order.
B) affirm the conviction because the defendant was provided with an attorney, but reverse the reimbursement order.
C) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was not properly informed of his rights.
D) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not informed of the consequences of waiving his right to a jury trial, but affirm the reimbursement order.
E) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not allowed to represent himself, but affirm the reimbursement order.
F) affirm the conviction, but not the reimbursement order.
G) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was denied the right to represent himself.
H) reverse the reimbursement order because it exceeds the maximum fine for grand larceny, but affirm the conviction.
I) affirm the reimbursement order, but not the conviction.
J) reverse the conviction because he was denied the right to a non-jury trial, but not the reimbursement order.

additional_args.input_str:
A riot broke out in a city, and many shops had been looted and some had been burned during the riots. Goods of all kinds were in piles or strewn about the sidewalk. During the riot, a defendant was walking along the street when he paused in front of an appliance store. He picked up a portable television set that was lying on the sidewalk and started to walk off quickly. A police officer who was standing in front of the shop rushed after the defendant and arrested him. The defendant, an indigent, was charged with grand larceny, a felony carrying the maximum penalty of seven months imprisonment and a S 1,000 fine. At his arraignment, the judge advised the defendant of his right to have counsel appointed for him. The defendant, however, told the judge that he wanted to represent himself and waive his right to a jury trial. The judge then questioned the defendant at length about his demands. The defendant indicated that he had no previous legal experience. He told the judge that the reason he didn't want a court-appointed attorney to represent him was because he didn't trust lawyers. The judge did not find the defendant's reasons for representing himself to be persuasive and appointed an attorney to represent him. Thereafter, an attorney was appointed by the court to represent the defendant. The attorney told the court that the defendant wanted a non-jury trial. However, at the prosecution's request, the court impaneled a jury. The defendant was subsequently convicted by the jury and sentenced to six months imprisonment. In addition, the defendant was ordered to reimburse the state $450 to cover the cost of his attorney. This reimbursement order was made pursuant to a relevant statute in effect at the time of the defendant's arrest. The defendant appeals both the conviction and the reimbursement order. The appellate court should

A) affirm both the conviction and the reimbursement order.
B) affirm the conviction because the defendant was provided with an attorney, but reverse the reimbursement order.
C) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was not properly informed of his rights.
D) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not informed of the consequences of waiving his right to a jury trial, but affirm the reimbursement order.
E) reverse the conviction because the defendant was not allowed to represent himself, but affirm the reimbursement order.
F) affirm the conviction, but not the reimbursement order.
G) reverse both the conviction and the reimbursement order because the defendant was denied the right to represent himself.
H) reverse the reimbursement order because it exceeds the maximum fine for grand larceny, but affirm the conviction.
I) affirm the reimbursement order, but not the conviction.
J) reverse the conviction because he was denied the right to a non-jury trial, but not the reimbursement order.
